articles.headline: Trump’s Interest in Buying Greenland Seemed Like a Joke. Then It Got Ugly.
articles.snippet: President Trump’s much-ridiculed Greenland venture comes at a time when he has seemed particularly erratic.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s much-ridiculed Greenland venture comes at a time when he has seemed particularly erratic.
articles.lead_paragraph: It started as a headline seemingly straight out of The Onion. Then it unleashed a torrent of jokes on late-night television and social media. And finally it exploded into a serious diplomatic rupture between the United States and one of its longtime allies.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Fed Was Divided About Interest Rate Cut
articles.snippet: Fed officials were split in their decision over whether to cut rates and by how much.
articles.abstract: Fed officials were split in their decision over whether to cut rates and by how much.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal Reserve officials were sharply divided when they voted to cut interest rates for the first time in a decade in late July, newly released minutes from their meeting show.

articles.headline: In the Trump Era, a Family’s Fight With Google and Facebook Over Disinformation
articles.snippet: The man behind “Willie Horton” and Citizens United built a potent online disinformation mill with his son. Then Big Tech changed the rules.
articles.abstract: The man behind “Willie Horton” and Citizens United built a potent online disinformation mill with his son. Then Big Tech changed the rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: Each day, in an office outside Phoenix, a team of young writers and editors curates reality.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore and Justin Bank

articles.headline: Bold Women. Scandalized Viewers. It’s ‘Sex and the City,’ Senegal Style.
articles.snippet: A hit TV show that unapologetically portrays female sexuality has thrilled many Senegalese. Except those who want it taken off the air.
articles.abstract: A hit TV show that unapologetically portrays female sexuality has thrilled many Senegalese. Except those who want it taken off the air.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — In the most controversial scene of “Mistress of a Married Man,” a hugely popular new television series in Senegal, the show’s protagonist, Marème, dons a daring magenta pantsuit and heads out for a date with a married man — but not before pointing below her belt.

articles.headline: Is Immigration at Its Limit? Not for Employers
articles.snippet: Restaurants, farms and other businesses say they need more foreign workers. And economic growth may depend on it, given lower birthrates.
articles.abstract: Restaurants, farms and other businesses say they need more foreign workers. And economic growth may depend on it, given lower birthrates.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — After finishing a particularly satisfying dinner at a Coral Gables restaurant with his wife, Pedro Martinez quietly slipped around to the back alley where the kitchen is.

articles.headline: Stephanie Grisham’s Turbulent Ascent to a Top White House Role
articles.snippet: The new press secretary and communications director is more behind-the-scenes facilitator than public face of the administration.
articles.abstract: The new press secretary and communications director is more behind-the-scenes facilitator than public face of the administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Stephanie Grisham doled out fast food and tracked lost gear as a press wrangler on President Trump’s 2016 campaign, far from the in-crowd flying on the gold-plated Trump jet. An early and hard-working convert to Mr. Trump’s cause, she told a reporter at one point that she was “riding it until the money runs out,” eager to return home to Arizona.

articles.headline: Ransomware Attacks Are Testing Resolve of Cities Across America
articles.snippet: As hackers lock up networks that power police forces and utilities, municipalities must operate with hobbled computer systems, and decide whether to pay ransoms.
articles.abstract: As hackers lock up networks that power police forces and utilities, municipalities must operate with hobbled computer systems, and decide whether to pay ransoms.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — At the public library in Wilmer, Tex., books were checked out not with the beeps of bar code readers but with the scratches of pen on notebook paper. Out on the street, police officers were literally writing tickets — by hand. When the entire computer network that keeps the small town’s bureaucracy afloat was recently hacked, Wilmer was thrown into the digital Dark Ages.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez, David E. Sanger and Marina Trahan Martinez

articles.headline: Trump Acclaims Economy, but Voters Are Anxious Amid Recession Talk
articles.snippet: Polling suggests that worries about the health of the economic expansion cross party lines.
articles.abstract: Polling suggests that worries about the health of the economic expansion cross party lines.
articles.lead_paragraph: Americans’ confidence in the economy is fragile, with a majority of voters expressing concern — a potential vulnerability for President Trump if the current economic slowdown worsens before next year’s election.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: Inside India’s Messy Electric Vehicle Revolution
articles.snippet: A million electric rickshaws sprang up out of nowhere and are now being used by 60 million people a day. The government and vehicle makers are struggling to catch up.
articles.abstract: A million electric rickshaws sprang up out of nowhere and are now being used by 60 million people a day. The government and vehicle makers are struggling to catch up.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — It’s the morning rush hour at Nawada metro station in India’s capital, and dozens of electric rickshaws are jockeying to get through the narrow gate into the parking lot. Once inside, each one stops to let its four or five passengers off before squeezing back out to pick up more riders.
articles.byline: By Saumya Khandelwal, Vindu Goel and Karan Deep Singh

articles.headline: Joe Biden’s Poll Numbers Mask an Enthusiasm Challenge
articles.snippet: There are signs of a disconnect between support for Mr. Biden in polls and excitement for his campaign on the ground in Iowa.
articles.abstract: There are signs of a disconnect between support for Mr. Biden in polls and excitement for his campaign on the ground in Iowa.
articles.lead_paragraph: PROLE, Iowa — Joseph R. Biden Jr. is coasting in the national polls. Surveys show him ahead of his Democratic rivals in hypothetical matchups against President Trump. He has maintained a lead in Iowa all summer, despite facing months of controversies over his record and his campaign missteps.

articles.headline: Massacred at Home, in Misery Abroad, 730,000 Rohingya Are Mired in Hopelessness
articles.snippet: Fear of what awaits them has kept the Rohingya from returning to Myanmar, where they were targets of ethnic cleansing. But life in Bangladesh refugee camps is intolerable. There’s no good place to go.
articles.abstract: Fear of what awaits them has kept the Rohingya from returning to Myanmar, where they were targets of ethnic cleansing. But life in Bangladesh refugee camps is intolerable. There’s no good place to go.
